posts.name: Christin Mohr
posts.cooked: Team 3278 is new to Swerve this year. We purchased MK4i Swerve with Neo Vortex motors and SPARK Flex motor controllers. We are struggling to find the correct shafts for the motors.  Any input would be appreciated.

posts.name: Adi Prajapati
posts.cooked: ive never worked with the neo vortex but i would assume its the Vortex Shaft - 8mm

It is the normal 8mm shaft. I suggest getting bearings and spacers to use in the top plate, they support the end of the shaft. Just to be warned there were issues with the vortex motors on the mk4i modules last year. The face plate of the motors will break for no reason. To my knowledge Rev never found a cure to the problem since it was only an issue with mk4i’s. We are swapping to Krakens this year so we don’t have to worry about it along with being able to put our drivetrain on its own can bus using a CANivore. I do have to say that the rpm boost of the vortex with L2 gearing was pretty darn quick, we tried the 16t pinion but lost acceleration and didn’t gain enough usable topend speed. The L2 with the standard 14t pinion had plenty of pushing power along with top speed. We did not have L3 gearing to try last year so i cannot say as to the feasibility of topend vs acceleration with the vortex motors. 20240316_135217 1920×2560 145 KB 20240316_135226 1920×2560 155 KB

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: My views are mine and mine alone

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
With that kind of damage I’d be checking for excessively long mounting screws… I believe you can set up the Vortex with all three types of shafts: 8mm keyed ( CIM style), Falcon spline, and Kraken spline. You need to look at your pinion gears and see which ones you have.

FYI, the steering pinion for an 8mm shaft on the MK4 regular is/was retained by loctite.  You’d be better off buying replacement -splined- pinions and the matching splined shaft.  The MK4i uses a keyed or splined gear and -does not- have this issue.

REV Robotics designs, builds and manufactures robotics parts and components used by students for learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our parts are commonly used within the FIRST Robotics Competition and the FIRST Tech...

Price: USD 12

The 8mm cim shaft is the correct shaft. The problem with vortex motors on mk4i is the cast face plate breaks. REV has changed the faceplates on the new version, they went to a machined faceplate instead of cast and it has stopped the problem as far as I know. We swapped to Krakens this past year and loved them. We will be slowly replacing all our REV motors over the next few years, we just don’t have the funds to do it all at once otherwise we would. We might keep a few 550s to use on the ultra planetary stuff we have but as far as neos and vortexes are concerned we are not getting anymore unless there is a design that we need the thru bore for.

posts.cooked: Starting in December 2024, the Neo Vortex manufacturing was changed from the front piece being cast to being CNC’d . In your pictures, the structure of the breaks makes me think it is one of the older cast motors.
It was if you look at the daye posted it was dec 24
